channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: South Korean President, Yoon Suk Yeol, Faces Impeachment Call from Own Party Leader
item.description: The leader of President Yoon Suk Yeol’s own party has backed impeachment, on which the National Assembly is set to vote on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: South Korea’s governing People Power Party leader, Han Dong-hoon, center, leaving his room at the National Assembly in Seoul on Friday.

item.title: South Korea’s Martial Law Declaration Stirs Memories in Gwangju
item.description: The last time South Korea imposed martial law, Gwangju endured a deadly crackdown. Han Kang, the Nobel Prize-winning author, told its story in “Human Acts.”
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Youngrae Kim for The New York Times
item.media:description: College students from across South Korea reading passages from Han Kang’s novel “Human Acts” at the May 18th National Cemetery in Gwangju to honor the victims of the pro-democracy uprising as part of a literary event this month.

item.title: Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris Reopens After 2019 Fire: What to Know
item.description: Millions of visitors will flock to the Parisian cathedral after it reopens in December for the first time since a destructive fire in 2019.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris, on Tuesday.

item.title: How Notre-Dame Was Reborn
item.description: It took about 250 companies, 2,000 workers, about $900 million, a tight deadline and a lot of national pride.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Jonathan Blezard

item.title: The V.I.P. Trains Shuttling World Leaders Like Biden to War-Torn Ukraine
item.description: With airspace closed and missiles flying, visiting Kyiv typically means 10 hours on bumpy tracks — even for presidents, prime ministers and business magnates. It’s plenty of time to reflect.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Since the early months of the war, Ukrzaliznytsia, the Ukrainian national railway, has deployed V.I.P. cars with bedrooms like these to shuttle dignitaries in and out of the country.

item.title: Romanian Court Annuls Presidential Election
item.description: The decision came days after the government asserted that there had been “cyberattacks” meant to undermine the vote and security council documents indicated possible Russian meddling.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins, Matei Barbulescu and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: A person voting in the first round of Romania’s presidential election in Sintesti, near Bucharest, Romania, in November.

item.title: As Trump Threatens Tariffs, Europe and South America Strengthen Ties
item.description: The European Union and four South American countries have reached an agreement to establish one of the largest trade zones in the world.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross, Liz Alderman and Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: The opening session on Thursday of a meeting in Montevideo, Uruguay, of the South American trade bloc Mercosur.

item.title: As India-Bangladesh Tensions Rise, So Do Fears of Tit-for-Tat Violence
item.description: A diplomatic dispute over claims of persecution of Bangladeshi Hindus threatens to upend Bangladesh’s interim government.
item.dc:creator: Pragati K.B., Anupreeta Das and Saif Hasnat
item.media:description: Members of the Vishwa Hindu Parishad, a Hindu-nationalist group, protesting outside a Bangladeshi diplomatic building in Mumbai, India, on Monday.

item.title: Syrian Rebels Push South, Despite Efforts to Slow Them
item.description: Government forces are said to be sending more troops to reinforce their most crucial strongholds, including Damascus, the capital, and the major city of Homs.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Muhammad Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rebels celebrated the capture of Hama, Syria, on Friday.

item.title: Israeli Attacks Around Kamal Adwan Hospital in Gaza Kill Scores, Doctors Say
item.description: Airstrikes, gunfire, panic and orders to evacuate in the dark of night combined to cause heavy casualties in the area of Kamal Adwan, one of the last hospitals still operating in northern Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: A wounded person is treated inside Kamal Adwan Hospital, in the northern Gaza Strip, after Israeli airstrikes and gunfire on the ground around the hospital on Friday, doctors say.

item.title: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer Is Fighting Populism From the Lonely Center Ground
item.description: One of the last centrist leaders left on the global stage, Prime Minister Keir Starmer this week outlined his plan to deliver change for people in the U.K. Will it be enough?
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Britain’s Prime Minister Keir Starmer at a news conference on migration at 10 Downing Street.

item.title: Canada Moves to Protect Arctic From Threats by Russia and China
item.description: Ottawa says its focus on the Arctic comes after Russia’s invasion of Ukraine “has shaken the foundations” of international cooperation in the northern region.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tuktoyaktuk, a hamlet in northern Canada, in September. Many Inuit communities in the high Arctic are reachable only by airfields that are often in poor repair.

item.title: Gazans With Disabilities Face ‘Impossible Times’ of Chaos and War
item.description: A family fled carrying a 9-year-old girl for hours on their backs. Sisters with visual impairments pleaded for help as Israeli airstrikes fell. “It’s a nightmare,” one wheelchair user said.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Bilal Shbair
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destruction after an airstrike west of Gaza City in October 2023. The war has been punishing for people with disabilities and their families.

item.title: For Macron, Notre-Dame’s Reopening Offers Respite From Political Crisis
item.description: The 860-year-old cathedral has been repaired in a time frame many thought impossible. But rather than basking in success, President Emmanuel Macron is mired in political crisis.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Christophe Petit Tesson
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France speaking inside the renovated Notre-Dame Cathedral during a sneak-peek tour last week.

item.title: Arsonists Set Fire to Melbourne Synagogue
item.description: Witnesses saw two people pouring accelerant in the synagogue early Friday, the police said. Australia’s prime minister condemned the attack as antisemitism.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: At the Adass Israel Synagogue in Melbourne, Australia, after an arson attack early Friday.

item.title: A $400 Billion Clean Energy Program Is Racing to Get Money Out the Door
item.description: Some fear Donald Trump could freeze the Energy Department’s loan office, which supports electric vehicles, geothermal, nuclear and other novel technologies.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: EVgo, an electric car charging company that was awarded a $1 billion loan guarantee in October, said it was “working diligently” to close its deal before the new administration took power.

item.title: Inside the Faithful Restoration of Notre-Dame
item.description: After Notre-Dame caught fire in 2019, France’s president, Emmanuel Macron, promised to reopen the cathedral in five years. The timeline seemed a Hail Mary. Yet here we are. Michael Kimmelman, architecture critic for The New York Times, brings us a behind-the-scenes look at the faithful restoration of Notre-Dame, which opens to the public on Dec. 8.
item.dc:creator: Michael Kimmelman, Christina Shaman and Laura Salaberry

item.title: Their Fertilizer Poisons Farmland. Now, They Want Protection From Lawsuits.
item.description: A company controlled by Goldman Sachs is helping to lead a lobbying effort by makers of fertilizer linked to “forever chemicals.”
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times

item.title: 3 Climbers From U.S. and Canada Presumed Dead on New Zealand’s Tallest Peak
item.description: The police suspended their search for two Americans and a Canadian who went missing while trying to reach the summit of Aoraki/Mount Cook.
item.dc:creator: Andrés R. Martínez
item.media:description: The search base at Aoraki/Mount Cook in New Zealand on Friday.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Caitlin Ochs for The New York Times
item.media:description: Investigators have not established a motive in the shooting.

item.title: McKinsey to Pay $122 Million to Settle South Africa Bribery Case
item.description: The global consultancy was accused of bribing foreign government officials. A former senior partner pleaded guilty to a conspiracy charge.
item.dc:creator: Michael Forsythe and Walt Bogdanich
item.media:credit: Gulshan Khan for The New York Times
item.media:description: McKinsey’s Johannesburg office. The firm entered into a deferred prosecution agreement with the Justice Department.

item.title: Shalom Nagar Dies; Reluctant Executioner of Adolf Eichmann
item.description: He was the hangman chosen to carry out the sentence on the fugitive Nazi war criminal, in Israel’s only case of capital punishment.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Shalom Nagar in “The Hangman,” a 2010 documentary about his role in the execution of Adolf Eichmann.

item.title: A Spate of Vandalism Rattled Estonia. Russia Was to Blame, Officials Say.
item.description: Several people were convicted in connection with small acts of vandalism carried out at the behest of Russia’s military intelligence service, prosecutors announced Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz

item.title: Emmanuel Macron Says He Won’t Resign France’s Presidency
item.description: A day after his chosen prime minister was forced to resign, President Emmanuel Macron denounced his political opponents.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Patrons at a cafe in Paris taking in President Emmanuel Macron’s speech on Thursday.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Syrian Rebels Storm Another City
item.description: Plus, a celebration of art in Dakar.
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:description: Syrian rebel fighters riding through the streets of Hama yesterday.

item.title: For Opponents Hiding from Venezuelan Government, No Food, Water or Power
item.description: Six leading opposition activists and advisers have taken refuge at the Argentine diplomatic residence for eight months. Now, the police are cutting off basic services.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:description: Venezuelan security forces outside the Argentine diplomatic residence in Caracas, where six leading government opposition figures have taken shelter for eight months.

item.title: Roommate Convicted in Murder of Kenyan Gay Rights Activist
item.description: Edwin Chiloba’s body was found stuffed inside a metal box by the roadside last year. A high court judge did not give a motive but said his roommate carried out the murder.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Relatives carrying portraits of a Kenyan activist whose killing caused international outrage among rights groups.

item.title: Ukraine Makes a Case to Trump’s Team as Its Officials Visit U.S.
item.description: Kyiv is feeling a sense of urgency leading up to the Jan. 20 inauguration, given the American president-elect’s vow to end the war quickly.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: Andriy Yermak, the chief of staff to President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, in Washington in July. Ukrainian officials have been appealing to both Democrats and Republicans since before the election.

item.title: Prince Johnson, 72, Warlord Who Executed Liberia’s President, Dies
item.description: A rebel leader in Liberia’s civil wars, he was accused of numerous atrocities. The most notorious was the videotaped mutilation and killing of President Samuel Doe.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Prince Johnson in 2008. He was accused of committing atrocities in Liberia’s civil wars, but he was never prosecuted.

item.title: Amnesty International Accuses Israel of Genocide in Gaza
item.description: Israel rejected the charge — the first of its kind by a major human rights organization — saying it was “based on lies.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A neighborhood in Khan Younis, in the southern Gaza Strip, after an Israeli airstrike this month.

item.title: Syrian Rebels Storm Hama as Government Forces Withdraw
item.description: Opposition forces advanced on the city of Hama as their startling offensive moved quickly in the direction of the capital, Damascus.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Bakr Al Kassem/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A rocket launcher firing against Syrian government forces on the outskirts of the city of Hama, Syria, on Wednesday.

item.title: South Korea’s Lawmakers Question Military About Yoon’s Martial Law Order
item.description: The military has spent decades trying to rehabilitate its image and win public trust after a brutal past. Its role in President Yoon’s martial law raised a specter from that era.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters urging President Yoon Suk Yeol to step down held a candlelight vigil in Seoul on Thursday.

item.title: How Global Conflicts Helped Reignite Syria’s Civil War
item.description: Rebels launched sweeping assaults against the forces of President Bashar al-Assad in northwestern Syria, taking control of large portions of territory, including much of the city of Aleppo. Carlotta Gall, a senior correspondent for The New York Times, explains how events beyond Syria’s borders lit the fuse for renewed fighting.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall, Nikolay Nikolov and James Surdam

item.title: Deadly Israeli Strike Hits Gaza Humanitarian Zone
item.description: The Israeli military said it was targeting senior Hamas militants in the area. Video from the scene showed the charred remains of tents.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: Palestinians running for cover as an explosion from an Israeli strike occurs near a makeshift camp in Gaza’s Al-Mawasi area on Wednesday.

item.title: American Kidnapped in Philippines Is Believed to Be Dead, Police Say
item.description: The police said they believed Elliot Eastman, 26, from Vermont, was killed during the abduction in October. They cited testimony from a suspect in custody.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses and Camille Elemia
item.media:credit: Philippine National Police Regional Office 9, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The police inspecting the area in Sibuco, the Philippines, where Elliot Eastman was kidnapped in October.

item.title: China Slaps Sanctions on 13 U.S. Defense Firms
item.description: The largely symbolic move is in response to the Biden administration’s latest arms sales to Taiwan, the island democracy that China considers its own.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taiwanese military during a live-fire drill in Pingtung, Taiwan, in 2022. As tensions rise with China, the United States has kept supplying arms to Taiwan.

item.title: Where Is Assisted Dying Legal? And What Countries Are Considering It?
item.description: Assisted dying is legal or partly legal in about a dozen countries, and more are considering allowing it.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: On Friday, as British lawmakers engaged in an emotional debate over a proposal to legalize assisted death for some people with terminally illnesses, supporters of the bill rallied in Parliament Square in London.

item.title: Coming for Selfies, Staying for Art: Dakar’s Biennale Draws Young Crowd
item.description: Encouraged by Senegal’s new president, teenagers and young adults, with social media tools in hand, have thronged an art exhibition that is usually the exclusive realm of the wealthy and elite.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Annika Hammerschlag for The New York Times
item.media:description: Posing for a photo beneath “Cotton Blues,” an art installation by Laeila Adjovi. Young people have flocked to this edition of the Dakar Biennale.

item.title: The Civil War in Ethiopia That Never Really Ended
item.description: A rare look inside a region still reckoning with the toll of war crimes, even as new conflicts roil the nation.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Okeowo
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Mekdes, 21, and Tihune, 22, are members of Fano, which is fighting against the central government, in Amhara. Mekdes, who joined more than a year ago, said her family supported her decision.

item.title: Brazil’s Most Common Surname Has a Grim Past
item.description: Silva, the surname of presidents and soccer stars, has long carried stigma over its colonial links. Now, many see its legacy in new ways.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil, in São Paulo in 2022, considers himself “just another Silva” according to his official biographer, Fernando Morais.

item.title: Old Photos Tell the Story of South Korea’s 1980 Unrest
item.description: Clashes during President Yoon Suk Yeol’s brief imposition of martial law echoed the military’s actions during an earlier political crisis that lasted longer and turned deadly.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Prime Minister Michel Barnier of France after the no-confidence vote.

item.title: South Korea’s Defense Minister Steps Down Over Martial Law Decree
item.description: President Yoon Suk Yeol accepted the resignation of Kim Yong-hyun, who said he took responsibility for the crisis caused by the brief imposition of military rule.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Defense Minister Kim Yong-hyun of South Korea in October.

item.title: Rohit Bal, Exuberant Star of Indian Fashion, Dies at 63
item.description: Known as “the bad boy of fashion,” he was among a wave of designers who created modern Indian couture by updating traditional garments.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.media:description: Rohit Bal at his showroom in 1997. His fashion design “created a path that people are now flamboyantly following,” said the filmmaker Mira Nair.

item.title: U.S. Defends Paris Climate Accord as ‘Best Hope’ at International Court of Justice
item.description: In a landmark international hearing on climate change, a U.S. representative backed the Paris Agreement, but left unanswered questions about U.S. commitments in a Trump presidency.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Robin Van Lonkhuijsen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Margaret L. Taylor, a legal adviser for the State Department, at the International Court of Justice in The Hague, Netherlands, on Wednesday.

item.title: Mexican Authorities Seize 20 Million Doses of Fentanyl in Record Haul
item.description: The operation comes after President-elect Donald J. Trump threatened tariffs on Mexico if the country did not crack down on fentanyl.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.media:description: Mexican soldiers deployed on a highway in Sinaloa state in October. Authorities said officers confiscated 800 kilograms of fentanyl in a house in Sinaloa state, home of the powerful Sinaloa Cartel and a hub of fentanyl production.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: An Impeachment Motion in South Korea
item.description: Plus, what’s your favorite holiday tradition?
item.dc:creator: Gaya Gupta
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of South Korea’s opposition parties protesting on the steps of the National Assembly in Seoul yesterday.

item.title: France’s Prime Minister Michel Barnier Loses No-Confidence Vote
item.description: Prime Minister Michel Barnier will most likely remain as a caretaker until a replacement is named. But the vote could create a wider opening for the far right.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Prime Minister Michel Barnier of France after the no-confidence vote in the National Assembly in Paris on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden Hopes Train Project in Angola Defines Africa Legacy
item.description: In his last announced trip abroad as president, Mr. Biden relished touring a U.S.-financed train line in Angola intended to transport goods and critical minerals to port.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: President Biden during a visit to the Lobito Port Terminal in Angola, on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel’s Military Says Hostages Were Likely Killed by Hamas as Airstrike Hit
item.description: The six hostages, whose bodies were found in Gaza over the summer, were probably shot in February by their captors as an Israeli strike hit close to the tunnel where they were held, the military said.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ruti Munder at the grave of her husband, Avraham Munder, in Israel in August.

item.title: Researchers Release Hawaiian Crows Back Into the Wild
item.description: Researchers are trying a new strategy to reintroduce Hawaiian crows, which have been extinct in the wild for two decades.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:credit: Jack Jeffrey, via Photo Resource Hawaii/Alamy
item.media:description: Only about 110 ʻalalā, or Hawaiian crows, remain on Earth.

item.title: South Korea’s Martial Law Turmoil Threatens Pacific Alliance With U.S. and Japan
item.description: Donald J. Trump had been seen as the main risk factor for the partnership between Tokyo, Seoul and Washington. Then came martial law in South Korea.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: President Biden with President Yoon Suk Yeol of South Korea, left, and Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba of Japan, right, in Peru last month. Their countries have been strengthening their ties, largely to counter China.

item.title: Map: Where Rebels Have Advanced in Syria
item.description: Syrian opposition fighters have rapidly expanded the territory under their control in northwestern Syria.
item.dc:creator: Samuel Granados

item.title: FIFA Secures $1 Billion Broadcast Deal With DAZN for Club World Cup
item.description: An agreement with the London-based streaming company DAZN came just a day before the draw for the inaugural event and after other networks balked at FIFA’s demands.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: DAZN is paying close to $1 billion to broadcast the inaugural Club World Cup, a soccer tournament featuring 32 men’s teams gathered from leagues across the globe.

item.title: South Korean Lawmakers Move to Impeach President Yoon After Failed Martial Law Bid
item.description: President Yoon Suk Yeol’s attempt to break a political deadlock by imposing military rule collapsed within hours, leaving him with few defenders. A vote to impeach him could come as soon as Friday.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun, John Yoon, Victoria Kim and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of South Korea’s opposition parties protesting on the steps of National Assembly in Seoul on Wednesday.

item.title: Georgia Tumbles Deeper Into Crisis as Government Detains Opposition Figures
item.description: In a sign of a widening crackdown, security agents have searched the offices and homes of prominent activists and opposition leaders who are furious about the government’s position on Europe.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:description: A still image taken from a video shows Nika Gvaramia, an opposition leader, surrounded by police officers before being detained in Tbilisi, Georgia, on Wednesday.

item.title: Elite Sumo Wrestlers Will Compete in London, a Rarity Outside Japan
item.description: A five-day event in October will be the Japan Sumo Association’s first competition in Britain in more than three decades.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: The sumo wrestlers Kitanowaka Daisuke and Fukutsuumi Akira of Japan outside Royal Albert Hall in London on Wednesday.
